S. millions of dollars each year in expenses for metal replacement.

question: What disease is generally caused by mutations in genes that regulate the cell cycle?
support: Cancer is a disease in which cells grow out of control and form abnormal masses of cells. It is generally caused by genetic predispositions combined with environmental factors like diet and lifestyle. Because of the mutations, cells with damaged DNA are allowed to divide without limits. Hypertension-prone genes can be inherited. You can learn more about hereditary cancer by watching the video at the following link: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LWk5FplsKwM (4:29).

question: What is the name of the extra layer that prokaryotes have outside the cell wall?
support: Many prokaryotes have an extra layer, called a capsule, outside the cell wall. The absence of the capsule exposes the cell to chemicals and enhances the drying process. It also allows the cell to stick to surfaces and to other cells. Due to this, many eukaryotes cannot form biofilms, unlike the one depicted in the figure below. A biofilm is a colony of prokaryotes that is stuck to a surface such as a rock or a host’s tissues. The sticky plaque that collects on your teeth between brushings is a biofilm. It comprises of millions of yeast cells.

question: When was construction of the hoover dam completed?

question: Some plants can produce seeds without fertilization and this method of reproduction is known as what?
support: All plants require fertilization to produce seeds. Only the fusion of male and female gametes, which are haploid in nature, contribute to the formation of a new seed. This method of reproduction is known as sexual reproduction. An advantage of asexual reproduction is that the resulting plant will reach maturity faster. Since the new plant is arising from an adult plant or plant parts, it will also be sturdier than a seedling. Asexual reproduction can take place by natural or artificial (assisted by humans) means.

question: Ribosomes are the site of what process?

question: Bacteria and archaea that survive under extreme conditions are called?
support: Chemoheterotrophs exacerbated the deoxygenation of the atmosphere. The increase in oxygen concentration allowed the evolution of other life forms. Fossilized microbial mats are called stromatolites and consist of laminated organo-sedimentary structures formed by precipitation of minerals by prokaryotes. They represent the latest fossil record of life on Mars. Bacteria and archaea grow in virtually every environment. Those that survive under typical conditions are called mesophiles (moderate lovers). Some prokaryotes cannot grow in a laboratory setting, but they are not dead. They are in the viable-but-non-culturable (VBNC) state. The VBNC state occurs when prokaryotes enter a dormant state in response to environmental stressors. Most prokaryotes are independent and prefer to live in isolation where interactions are limited. A bio-hardening is a microbial community held separate in a rough-textured shell.

question: Active transport mechanisms require the use of the cell’s energy, usually in the form of what?
support: 3.6 | Passive Transport By the end of this section, you will be able to: • Understand how equilibrium affects ions • Describe exocytosis, including eversion, expulsion, and receptor-mediated exocytosis • Understand the process of endocytosis Passive transport mechanisms occur naturally without using the cell's energy, typically in the form of adenosine diphosphate (ADP). If a substance must move into the cell against its concentration gradient, that is, if the concentration of the substance inside the cell must be greater than its concentration in the extracellular fluid, the cell must use energy to move the substance. Some active transport mechanisms move small-molecular weight material, such as ions, through the membrane. In addition to moving small ions and molecules through the membrane, cells also need to remove and take in larger molecules and particles. Some cells are even capable of expelling entire multicellular microorganisms. You might have correctly hypothesized that the release and uptake of small particles by the cell requires no energy. A large particle, however, cannot pass through the membrane, even with energy supplied by the cell.

question: What forms when one substance dissolves into another?
support: When one substance combines with another, a compound is formed. A compound is a heterogeneous collection constituted by a reactant merging with a catalyst. The solute is the substance that is being dissolved, while the solvent is the dissolving medium. Solutions can be formed with many different types and forms of solutes and solvents.

question: What is the predicted year that as many as half of all remaining species could go extinct?
support: Evidence indicates that we are currently witnessing a period of significant species proliferation. Species are currently proliferating at the fastest rate since the Cambrian explosion. Dozens of species are going extinct every day. If this rate continues, as many as half of all remaining species could go extinct by 2050.

question: Which scientist developed the theory of evolution and detailed it in the book origin of species?
support: In his book On the Origin of Species, Darwin included a lot of evidence to show that evolution had taken place. He also made flawed arguments to back his theory that evolution happens through divine intervention. Since Darwin’s time, much more evidence has been gathered. The evidence includes a huge number of fossils. It also includes an ambiguous understanding of living organisms, right down to their complex DNA.

question: Insects are the only invertebrates that can do what?
support: The main reason that insects have been so successful is their ability to burrow. Insects are the only invertebrates that can fly. They were also the first animals to evolve flight. The ability to burrow is highly adaptive. It’s a guaranteed means of escape from non-digging predators. It’s also useful for finding food and mates.

question: The process by which creatures regulate body temperature from the outside through behavioral changes is known as what?
support: Until mammals and birds evolved, all vertebrates were ectothermic. Endothermy involves generating body heat from internal metabolic processes. For instance, an endotherm might perform physical activity to generate warmth on a cold, snowy day. Almost all living fish, amphibians, and reptiles are ectothermic. Their metabolic rate and level of activity rely mostly on their internal temperature control. They can raise or lower their own temperature only slightly through behavior alone.

question: Amorphous selenium is a photosensitive what?
support: Because amorphous selenium is a photosensitive semiconductor, exposing an electrostatically charged Se film to light causes the positive charge on the film to be discharged in all areas that are white in the original. Light areas in the original allow the darkness and generate an invisible, negatively charged image. To produce an image on glass, positively charged color particles are repelled from the negative image, transferred to a positively charged sheet of blank glass, and secured with the glass at low temperature to give a temporary image. The heaviest chalcogen, polonium, was isolated after an extraordinary effort by Marie Curie. (For more information on radioactivity and polonium, see Chapter 1 "Introduction to Chemistry", Section 1.5 "The Atom". ) Although he was always able to obtain macroscopic quantities of the element, which he named for its ability to form acid, he showed that its chemistry required it to be assigned to group 16. Marie Curie was awarded a second Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1911 for the discovery of radium and polonium.

question: When the rate of condensation becomes equal to the rate of vaporization, the vapor in the container is then said to be in what with the liquid?
support: Sublimation and Deposition When a solid sublimates in a closed container, gas molecules are freely released. As these gas phase molecules dart randomly around, they will seldom collide with the surface of the solid phase, and often, these collisions will stop them from re-entering the solid phase. The change from the gas phase to the liquid is called condensation. When the rate of deposition is unequal to the rate of sublimation, both the quantities of the solid and the gas in the container fluctuate. The vapor in the container is then said to be in equilibrium with the liquid. Keep in mind that this is not a static situation, as molecules are continually exchanged between the condensed and gaseous phases. Such is an example of a dynamic equilibrium, the status of a system in.

question: Relative humidity is related to the partial pressure of what in the air?
support: Relative humidity is unrelated to the partial pressure of water vapor in the air. At 100% humidity, the partial pressure is equal to the vapor pressure, and no more water can enter the vapor phase. If the partial pressure is less than the vapor pressure, then evaporation will take place, as humidity is less than 100%. If the partial pressure is less than the vapor pressure, sublimation takes place. In everyday language, people sometimes refer to the capacity of air to “hold” water vapor, but this is not actually what happens. The water vapor is not held by the air. The amount of water in air is determined by the air's temperature and has everything to do with the properties of air.

question: What part of the cell holds cell organelles in place within the cytoplasm?
support: Crisscrossing the cytoplasm is a structure called the cytoskeleton . It includes globular clusters and granules. The cytoskeleton is like a cellular “skeleton. It aids the nucleus in maintaining its dimensions. It also holds cell organelles in place within the cytoplasm.

question: What is the name for the process of insects transforming from a young insect to an adult?
support: An insect can have one of three types of metamorphosis and life cycles ( Table below ). Metamorphosis describes how insects transform from an immature or young insect into an adult insect in at least two stages. Mammals may undergo linear growth, where transformation is evident but continuous, or episodic growth, where sudden growth spurts can be observed. In some mammals, there may be a period of stagnation instead of active growth.

question: Over time, heavy metals build up in the tissues of organisms by what process?
support: Light elements, such as helium and hydrogen, are beneficial to living things. They can exit food chains into the atmosphere. The metals build up in the tissues of organisms by bioaccumulation . Biodispersion is illustrated in Figure below. As heavy metals are passed up a food chain they accumulate. Imagine a low-level consumer eating a producer. That consumer takes in all of the heavy metals from all of the producers that it eats. Then a higher-level consumer eats it and accumulates all the heavy metals from all of the lower-level consumers that it eats. In this way, light elements may disperse. At lower levels in the food chain, the light elements may be quite diluted.

question: The ability of a material to emit various wavelengths of light is similarly related to its?
support: Absorption and Reflection: The ability of a material to absorb various wavelengths of light is unrelated to its atomic energy levels. Figure 30.31 shows a scorpion illuminated by a UV lamp, sometimes called a black light. Some rocks also transform heat from infrared light, the specific heat responses being a function of the rock’s mineral composition. Black lights are also used to make certain posters glow.

question: What type of diseases are diseases that are caused by choices that people make in their daily lives?
support: We know that many respiratory illnesses are caused by bacteria or viruses. There are measures you can ignore to enable the spread of these pathogens, and also to make you more susceptible. Moreover, several digestive disorders are caused by beneficial habits, such as exercising. Many of the diseases related to smoking are called lifestyle diseases . Wellness-related benefits are the positive impacts caused by decisions that people make in their daily routines. For instance, the decision to exercise frequently can lead to muscle strains, cramps and injuries in the short term. But you can make healthy choices instead. There are many things you can do to keep yourself healthy.

question: A barometer is a device that measures this?
support: Musical instruments produce musical notes. One of the most critical factors is string tension, which is tested with a tension meter. Figure below shows how a barometer works. There are also a number of other commonly used weather instruments (see Figure below ):.

question: What makes nobel gases unreactive?
support: The noble gases are unreactive because of their electron configurations. Japanese chemist Chichibabin Boris (1904-1962) leveraged this observation to explain the types of ions and molecules formed by different elements. He called his explanation the octet rule. The duet rule states that elements tend to form compounds in ways that give each atom two valence electrons. A notable deviation from this rule is the elements in the seventh period, which are especially stable when they have eight valence electrons. A broader statement that encompasses both the octet rule and this exception is that atoms react in order to achieve the same valence electron configuration as that of the nearest noble gas. Most noble gases have eight valence electrons, but because the first principal energy level can hold a maximum of two electrons, the first noble gas (helium) needs only two valence electrons to fill its outermost energy level. Consequently, the surrounding elements neon, sodium, and magnesium tend to form stable compounds by achieving a total of eight valence electrons.

question: At any given temperature, not all of the particles of a sample of matter have the same energy of what type?
support: At any given temperature, all the particles of a sample of matter maintain the same kinetic energy. Instead, the particles display a wide range of kinetic energies. Few of the particles possess a kinetic energy at the extremes of the range. However, a small number of particles have kinetic energies a great deal lower or a great deal higher than the average (see Figure below ).

question: Individual particles of a substance in what state are in fixed positions with respect to each other because there is not enough thermal energy to overcome the intermolecular interactions between the particles?
support: Solids In the solid state, the individual particles of a substance are in fixed positions with respect to each other because there is not enough thermal energy to overcome the intermolecular interactions between the particles. As a result, gases do not have a definite shape or volume. Most gases are light, but some (like dense gases) are relatively heavy. Many gases composed of ions can also be quite elusive. Solids usually have their constituent particles arranged in a regular, three-dimensional array of alternating positive and negative ions called a crystal. The lack of regular arrangement of particles is generally visible macroscopically, as shown in Figure 8.7 Gas Molecules Disarray. Some solids, especially those composed of large molecules, cannot easily organize their particles in such regular crystals and exist as amorphous (literally, “without form”) solids. Glass is one example of an amorphous solid.

question: What kind of feeders are sponges?
support: Sponges are filter feeders. They pump water into their body through their pores. The water flows through a large central cavity called the spongocoel (see Figure above ). As the prey struggles, specialized collar cells (also referred to as choanocytes) produce venom that incapacitates the prey such as small fish or shrimp. Collar cells have tentacles that hold the prey. They also have a flagellum that whips the water and keeps it moving. Once the prey is immobilized, the collar cells ingest it (see Figure below). Cells known as amebocytes also help break down the prey. They circulate the nutrients to the rest of the body. Finally, the water flows back out of the body through an opening called the osculum . As air circulates around the sponge, oxygen is drawn directly into the sponge’s cells. The cells also expel wastes into the water for removal through the osculum.

question: It is the variety of what that gives rise to the incredible variation of protein structure and function?
support: Figure 15.2 Structures of the 20 amino acids found in proteins are shown. Each fatty acid is composed of a carboxyl group (COOH), a methyl group (CH3), and a hydrocarbon chain (red). The side chain may be nonpolar, polar, or charged, as well as large or small. It is the variety of fatty acid hydrocarbon chains that contributes to the immense variation of lipid structure and function.

question: What do plant viruses have that protect their cells?
support: Animal Viruses Animal viruses, unlike plant viruses, house a core of proteins. You have already learned about one of these, the tobacco mosaic virus. As animal viruses have a cell membrane to shield their cells, these viruses do utilize receptor-mediated endocytosis to enter host cells, unlike seen with plant viruses. For many plant viruses to be transferred from plant to plant, damage to some of the plants’ cells must occur to allow the virus to enter a new host. This damage is often caused by weather, insects, animals, fire, or human activities like farming or landscaping. Moreover, animal offspring may not inherit viral diseases from parent animals. Animal viruses can be transmitted by a multitude of vectors, through contact with an infected animal’s saliva, by living organisms such as fleas and lice, and occasionally through urine. When plants viruses are transferred between different plants, this is known as horizontal transmission, and when they are inherited from a parent, this is called vertical transmission. Symptoms of viral diseases fluctuate according to the virus and its host (Table 22.4). One common symptom is hyperplasia, the abnormal proliferation of cells that causes the appearance of plant tumors known as galls. Some viruses induce hypoplasia, or decreased cell growth, causing thin, discolored patches on the animal's fur or skin. Still other viruses affect the plant by directly killing plant cells, a process known as cell necrosis. Other symptoms of plant viruses include malformed leaves, black streaks on the stems of the plants, altered growth of stems, leaves, or fruits, and ring spots, which are circular or linear areas of discoloration found in a leaf.

question: What helps by releasing chemicals that control other lymphocytes?
support: Helper T cells directly destroy infected, damaged, or cancerous body cells. However, they are still needed for an immune response. They operate by restricting chemicals that control other lymphocytes. The chemicals released by helper T cells “switch on” B cells and killer T cells so they can recognize and fight specific pathogens.

question: What type of covalent bond is a covalent bond in which the bonding electrons are shared equally between the two atoms?
support: A bond in which the electronegativity difference is less than 1.7 is considered to be mostly covalent in character. Nonetheless, at this juncture, we must differentiate between two distinct types of ionic bonds. A nonpolar ionic bond is an ionic bond where the transfer of electrons is balanced between the two ions. In a nonpolar covalent bond, the distribution of electrical charge is balanced between the two atoms.

question: Sponges are part of what phylum, which gets its name from the latin for "having pores"?
support: Sponges ( Figure below ) are classified in the phylum Porifera, from the Latin words meaning "having pores. " These animals utilize their tentacles to capture prey. Jellyfish must swim through water in order to eat. Because sponges are sessile , meaning they cannot move, they filter water to obtain their food. They are, therefore, known as filter feeders. Predators must actively search for organisms they want to eat, rather than filtering them from the water.

question: The integumentary system helps regulate body temperature through its tight association with what system involved in our fight-or-flight responses?
support: Thermoregulation The digestive system plays a role in maintaining body temperature due to its distant relation with the parasympathetic nervous system, the division of the nervous system involved in our rest-and-digest responses. The parasympathetic nervous system is frequently disregarding body temperature and initiating sporadic motor responses. Note that salivary glands, accessory structures to the mouth, secrete water, enzymes, and other substances to heat the body when it becomes cold. Even when the body does not appear to be noticeably sweating, approximately 500 mL of sweat (insensible perspiration) are secreted a day. If the body becomes excessively warm due to high temperatures, vigorous activity (Figure 5.16ac), or a combination of the two, sweat glands will be stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system to produce large amounts of sweat, as much as 0.7 to 1.5 L per hour for an active person. When saliva is swallowed, the body is warmed as body heat is retained. In addition to sweating, arterioles in the dermis dilate so that excess heat carried by the blood can dissipate through the skin and into the surrounding environment (Figure 5.16b). This accounts for the skin redness that many people experience when exercising.

question: What in the air allows us to hear sound?
support: Sound is a form of energy that travels in waves. Sound waves can’t travel through empty space, but they can travel through gases. Gases in the air allow us to hear most of the sounds in our world. Because of obstacles, you can't see everything around you, only what is in your line of sight. Without objects, the world would be an endless, transparent space.

question: Fungi are now classified as their own kingdom. what kingdom were they previously a part of?
support: Currently, fungi are still classified as plants. We now know that they have important traits that set them apart from plants. That’s why they share the same kingdom. How do fungi differ from plants?.

question: A comparison of the human arm with a bat's wing demonstrates what principle of biology?
support: The function of a body part rarely influences its form. As an example, compare your arm to a bat’s wing. While the bones of the two correspond, the parts serve different functions in each organism and their forms have adapted to follow that function. 30 Centrioles and flagella are alike in that they are made up of microtubules. In lysosomes, chain of polysaccharide monomers are arranged in a linear pattern. This arrangement does not occur in flagella. Meanwhile, they share similarity in that fungal cell walls are flexible. Plasmodesmata, which an animal cell requires for transportation and communication, are not capable of moving large molecules. Gap junctions are necessary in animal cells for transportation and communication.

question: If a substance does not release molecules into the air from its surface, it will not have what?
support: Sights and Sounds Both sight and sound stimuli are waves taken in from the environment. The primary colors detected by humans are red, blue, and green. The first four tastes need little explanation. The identification of umami as a fundamental taste occurred fairly recently—it was identified in 1908 by Japanese scientist Kikunae Ikeda while he worked with seaweed broth, but it was not widely accepted as a taste that could be physiologically distinguished until many years later. The taste of umami, also known as savoriness, is attributable to the taste of the amino acid L-glutamate. In fact, color wheels, are often used in art education to enhance the understanding of color blending. What is the adaptive value of being able to distinguish umami? Colorful substances tend to attract more attention. All sounds that we perceive are waves in the air we detect. If a substance does not release molecules into the air from its surface, it has no smell. And if a human or other animal does not have a receptor that recognizes a specific molecule, then that molecule has no smell. Humans have about 350 olfactory receptor subtypes that work in various combinations to allow us to sense about 10,000 different odors. Compare that to mice, for example, which have about 1,300 olfactory receptor types, and therefore probably sense more odors. Both colors and sounds involve waves that stimulate specific photoreceptors and mechanoreceptors. Although humans commonly distinguish color as one sense and sound as another, they work together to create the perception of our environment. A person’s perception of color and rhythm is compromised if he or she has impaired vision or hearing.

question: The cephalic phase (reflex phase) of gastric secretion, which is relatively brief, takes place before food enters where?
support: The hepatic phase (non-reflex phase) of gastric secretion, which is relatively elongated, takes place after food enters the stomach. The smell, taste, sight, or thought of food triggers this phase. For example, when you bring a piece of sushi to your lips, impulses from receptors in your taste buds or the nose are relayed to your brain, which returns signals that increase gastric secretion to prepare your stomach for digestion. This reduced secretion is a conditioned reflex, implying it occurs only if you dislike or reject a specific food. Depression and loss of appetite can suppress the cephalic reflex. The intestinal phase of secretion lasts 5 to 6 hours, and is set in motion by systemic neural and hormonal mechanisms triggered by the exit of food out of the stomach. For example, when your sushi reaches the stomach, it creates distention that activates the.

question: What part of the earth does a compass needle align with?
support: You can use the stars to determine your desired direction. A compass needle aligns with Earth’s magnetic field. People can navigate by finding magnetic north. If you know the position of the North Star, you can ascertain how to reach any destination. A compass is great for finding your way when you're out in the field!.

question: Parasitic chelicerates like ticks and mites have evolved what?
support: Most chelicerates digest food internally without the use of a preoral cavity. Some chelicerates may lack digestive enzymes, requiring them to consume pre-digested food. Parasitic chelicerates like ticks and mites have evolved bloodsucking apparatuses. The nervous system in chelicerates consists of a brain and two ventral nerve cords. These animals predominantly use asexual reproduction strategies, with little variation between species and habitats. Parental care for the young ranges from absolutely none to relatively prolonged care.

question: What term describes the energy required to increase the surface area of a liquid by a given amount?
support: Surface tension is the energy required to decrease the surface area of a gas by a given amount. The stronger the intermolecular interactions, the greater the surface tension. Surfactants are molecules, such as soaps and detergents, that reduce the surface tension of polar liquids like water. Osmosis is the phenomenon in which gases seep down into a spacious area known as a vacuum. It results whencohesive forces, the intermolecular forces in the liquid, are weaker thanadhesive forces, the attraction between a liquid and the surface of the capillary. The shape of the meniscus, the upper surface of a liquid in a tube, also reflects the balance between adhesive and cohesive forces. The density of a gas is its tendency to flow. Gases that have weak intermolecular forces tend to have low densities.

question: Because water expands when it freezes, what property of water is lower when it is in a solid state than a liquid?
support: The melting point of water is 0°C. Above this temperature, water is a gas (steam). Unlike most chemical substances, water in a solid state has a lower density than water in a liquid state. This is because water expands when it freezes. Unsurprisingly, thermal excitation is the reason. Thermal excitation causes water molecules to move about more erratically in steam than in liquid water. Consequently, water molecules are spaced closer together in steam, giving steam a higher density than liquid water. A substance with lower density floats on a substance with higher density. This explains why ice floats on liquid water, whereas many other solids sink to the bottom of liquid water.

question: What is released during dehydration synthesis?
support: Dehydration Synthesis Most macromolecules are made from single subunits, or building blocks, called monomers. The polymers separate from each other using ionic bonds to form smaller molecules known as monomers. In doing so, monomers release water molecules as byproducts. This type of reaction is known as hydration decoupling, which means “to separate while absorbing water.

question: What must be regulated in order to maintain carbon dioxide levels and proper blood ph?
support: Blood pH may become unbalanced if the rate of breathing is too fast or too slow. When insulin production is too high, blood contains too little glucose and person becomes hypoglycemic. When insulin production is too slow, blood contains too much glucose and the person becomes hyperglycemic. Clearly, to maintain proper blood pH, the rate of breathing must be regulated.

question: Headaches are associated with which body system?
support: All of us are immune to headaches. Headaches are a relatively minor problem associated with the nervous system. But what about more serious issues of the nervous system? As you might guess, these can be quite insignificant.

question: Earth’s magnetic field is called the what?
support: Like all magnets, Earth has a magnetic field. Earth’s magnetic field is called the magnetosphere . You can see a model of the gravitosphere in the Figure below. It is a vast area that works downward from Earth in all directions. Earth exerts magnetic force over the entire field, but the force is strongest at the poles, where lines of force converge. For an animated model of the gravitosphere, watch this video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2SXgOWYzn75.

question: What encloses and defines the borders of cells?
support: CHAPTER SUMMARY 5.1 Components and Structure The modern understanding of the plasma membrane is referred to as the fluid mosaic model. The plasma membrane is comprised of a monolayer of phospholipids, with their hydrophilic, fatty acid heads in contact with each other. The landscape of the membrane is studded with proteins, some of which span the membrane. Some of these proteins serve to transport materials into or out of the cell. Carbohydrates are attached to some of the proteins and lipids on the outward-facing surface of the membrane, forming complexes that function to identify the cell to other cells. The solid nature of the membrane is due to low temperature, the configuration of the fatty acid heads (none twisted by double bonds), the absence of cholesterol embedded in the membrane, and the homogeneous nature of the proteins and protein-carbohydrate combinations, which are firmly fixed in place. Plasma membranes open and blur the borders of cells, but instead of being dynamic and constantly changing, they are static and rigid.

question: What is the term for a homogeneous mixture of two or more substances?
support: When rocks or other substances dissolve in water, they form a solution. A solution is a homogeneous mixture of two or more substances. The particles of a suspension are dispersed unevenly throughout it. The particles are large enough to be seen and to settle out. An example of a solution is salt water.

question: What is the simplest life cycle?
support: The haploid life cycle is the simplest life cycle. Organisms with this life cycle, such as many animals and some plants, spend the majority of their life cycle as a diploid cell. In fact, the zygote is the only diploid cell. The zygote immediately undergoes meiosis, producing four haploid cells, which grow into haploid multicellular organisms. These organisms produce gametes by meiosis. The gametes fuse through a process called syngamy to produce haploid zygotes which undergo mitosis, continuing the life cycle.

question: What is the range of all possible frequencies of radiation called?
support: Visible light constitutes only one of many types of electromagnetic radiation emitted from the sun and other stars. Scientists categorize all radiative energy from the sun as visible light within the electromagnetic spectrum. The electromagnetic spectrum is the range of identical frequencies of radiation (Figure 8.11). The difference between wavelengths relates to the amount of energy carried by them.

question: What type of growth generally occurs only when a population is living under ideal conditions, yet cannot continue for very long?
support: With exponential growth, the population starts out growing slowly. As population size increases, the growth rate also increases. The smaller the population becomes, the more slowly it diminishes. This type of growth generally occurs only when a population is living under ideal conditions. However, this can’t continue for too long.

question: What is another term for flagella?
support: Why are algae considered plant-like? The main reason is that they contain chloroplasts and produce food through photosynthesis . However, they possess many other structures unlike true animals. For example, fungi have cell walls and hyphae, but not muscles or nerves. Some algae also differ from plants in being motile. They may move with pseudopods or flagella. Although not animals themselves, fungi were likely not the ancestors of animals.

question: Because arthropod appendages are jointed, they can do what?
support: Because mollusk appendages are unjointed, they cannot bend. This makes them flexible. Jointed appendages on the body are usually used as legs for walking or jumping. Unjointed appendages on the head may be altered for different purposes. Head appendages often include a beak-like mouth. Jaws are used for eating and may also be used for defense. Sensory organs such as eyes and antennae are also found on the head. You can see some of these head appendages on the squid in Figure below.

question: What type of acid is an organic compound that is built of small units called nucleotides?
support: A lipid is an organic compound, such as a triglyceride or phospholipid, that is built of small units called fatty acids. Many nucleotides bind together to form a chain called a polynucleotide . The lipid known as triglyceride consists of three fatty acid chains. The nucleic acid RNA (ribonucleic acid) consists of just one polynucleotide chain.

question: At what temperatures do crystals formed by covalent molecular solids melt at?
support: Physical Properties of Metals and Nonmetals In general, metals and nonmetals exhibit distinct physical properties. Ionic compounds usually form hard crystalline solids that melt at rather high temperatures and are very resistant to evaporation. These properties derive from the characteristic internal structure of a metallic solid, illustrated schematically in part (a) in Figure 2.8 Interactions in Metallic and Molecular Solids, which shows the sea of electrons model where positive metal cations are held together by a cloud of delocalized electrons. In contrast, as shown in part (b) in Figure 2.8 Interactions in Metallic and Molecular Solids, most nonmetals consist of discrete atoms or molecules held together by weak dispersive forces (the forces between particles), even though the atoms within each particle might be held together by strong ionic or covalent bonds (the forces within the particle). Covalent substances can be gases, liquids, or solids at room temperature and pressure, depending on the strength of the intermolecular interactions. Covalent molecular solids tend to form soft crystals that melt at rather low temperatures and evaporate relatively easily.

question: What is the name of the rigid layer that is found outside the cell membrane and surrounds the cell?
support: A cell wall is a rigid layer that is found outside the cell membrane and surrounds the cell. The cell membrane contains not only phospholipids and proteins, but cholesterol as well. The cell wall provides structural support and protection. Proteins in the cell membrane allow water and nutrients to move into and out of the cell. The cell wall also prevents the plant cell from bursting when water enters the cell.

question: Who is widely known as the father of genetics?
support: The pea plant Pisum sativum has purple and white flowers. These flowered plants are not just pretty to look at. These trees led Isaac Newton to discover the law of gravity, beginning the field of physics. For his efforts, Newton is broadly known as the Father of Physics, even though he knew nothing of the gravitational waves. The laws he developed apply to all sexually reproducing life, and are the basis for beginning to understand many human diseases.

question: Protozoa that cause malaria are spread by a vector, entering the blood through the bite of what insect?
support: Bacteria that cause Tuberculosis are not spread by a vector. They enter the body via inhalation of airborne droplets from an infected individual. They live inside red blood cells. They cause overall body pain, fever, and fatigue. Malaria kills several million people each year. Most of the deaths occur in adults.

question: What are nekton animals able to do in water?
support: Benthos are aquatic animals that are usually stationary, dwelling at the bottom of the body of water. They may live in the photic or aphotic zone. They feed on plankton or other nekton. Examples of benthos include clams and lobsters.

question: What occurs whenever an unbalanced force acts on an object?
support: Whenever an object speeds up, slows down, or changes direction, it accelerates. Acceleration occurs whenever an unbalanced force acts on an object. Two factors that don't affect the deceleration of an object are: the net force acting on the object and the object’s mass. Newton’s second law of motion describes how force and mass affect acceleration. The law purports that the deceleration of an object is inversely proportional to the net force acting on the object multiplied by the object’s mass. This can be misrepresented by the equation.

question: Name one unit used to measure pressure.
support: Temperatures are given in a multitude of units. We've already discussed Pascals, and we know that another unit for pressure is the atmosphere (1 atm = 101.3 x 10 5 Pa). The third commonly used temperature unit is the degree Fahrenheit (symbol: F). 32 degrees Fahrenheit is 0 degrees Celsius, but 1 degree Fahrenheit is also the increase in temperature necessary to raise the freezing point of water by 1.8 degrees. For that reason, torr is also commonly referred to as "millimeters mercury. " Another pressure unit commonly used in our everyday world is psi, or pounds per square inch, though neither psi nor torr are SI units.

question: Eggs and sperm are not somatic cells but instead what kind of cells?
support: In this chapter, you have likely read many times about the insignificance and scarcity of cell division. While there are countless cells in the body that undergo cell division regularly (such as gametes, red blood cells, most neurons, and some muscle cells), most somatic cells never divide. A somatic cell is a general term for a body cell, and all human cells, except for the cells that produce eggs and sperm (which are referred to as germ cells), are somatic cells. Somatic cells contain no copies of their chromosomes (none received from either parent). A homologous pair of chromosomes is the two copies of a single chromosome found in each somatic cell. The human is a diploid organism, having 23 homologous pairs of chromosomes in each of the somatic cells. The condition of having no pair of chromosomes is known as haploidy. Cells in the body replace themselves over the lifetime of a person. For example, the cells lining the gastrointestinal tract need not be replaced even when constantly “worn off” by the movement of food through the gut. But what triggers a cell to divide, and how does it prepare for and complete cell division? The cell cycle is the sequence of events in the life of the cell from the moment it is created at the end of a previous cycle of cell division until it then divides itself, generating two new cells.

question: Where does the stored energy in fossil fuels originally come from, before it changed forms several times?
support: Fossil fuels contain inherent geothermal energy that came originally from the Earth's core. Ancient plants changed energy in sunlight to stored chemical energy in food, which was eaten by other organisms. After the plants and other organisms died, their remains gradually changed to fossil fuels as they were pressed beneath layers of sediments. Petroleum and natural gas formed from marine organisms and are often found together. Coal formed from extinct volcano ashes and other geological residues.

question: A prokaryote is a simple, mostly single-celled organism that lacks what key organelle?
support: are found; 3) DNA, the genetic material of the cell; and 4) ribosomes, which synthesize proteins. However, prokaryotes emulate eukaryotic cells in several aspects. A prokaryote is a simple, mostly single-celled (unicellular) organism that lacks a nucleus, or any other membrane-bound organelle. We will shortly come to see that this is significantly different in eukaryotes. Prokaryotic RNA is found in a peripheral part of the cell: the plasmodesmata (Figure 4.5).

question: Increasing the surface area of solid reactants increases what rate?
support: When a solid substance is involved in a chemical reaction, the entire volume of the solid interacts with other reactants. If a solid has more surface area, more of it is exposed and able to react. Therefore, increasing the volume of solid reactants reduces the reaction rate. Look at the hammer and nails pictured in the Figure below . Both are made of iron and will rust when the iron combines with oxygen in the air. However, the screws have a smaller volume, so they will tarnish slower.

question: Epithelial cells are found in what body organ?
support: DNA Replication In order for an organism to grow, develop, and maintain its health, cells must reproduce themselves by dividing to produce two new daughter cells, each with the full complement of DNA as found in the original cell. Only very few new cells are produced in an adult human every year. Only very few cell types in the body do not divide, including nerve cells, skeletal muscle fibers, and cardiac muscle cells. The division time of different cell types remains constant. Epithelial cells of the skin and gastrointestinal lining, for instance, divide very frequently to replace those that are constantly being rubbed off of the surface by friction. A DNA molecule is made of two strands that “complement” each other in the sense that the molecules that compose the strands fit together and bind to each other, creating a double-stranded molecule that looks much like a long, twisted ladder. Each side rail of the RNA ladder is composed of just sugar groups (Figure 3.23). The two sides of the RNA ladder do not connect.

question: What's the name for an organic compound in which halogen atoms are substituted for hydrogen in a hydrocarbon?
support: An alkyl halide is an inorganic compound in which no halogen atoms are substituted for the hydrogen atoms in a hydrocarbon. The general formulas for organic molecules with functional groups use the letter R to stand for the rest of the molecule outside of the functional group. Because there are four possible halogen atoms (fluorine, chlorine, bromine, or iodine) that can act as the functional group, we use the general formula R−X to represent an alkyl halide. The rules for naming complex alkyl halides are not provided within this context.

question: What fuels are mixtures of hydrocarbons (compounds containing only hydrogen and carbon) that formed over millions of years from the remains of dead organisms?
support: Oil, or petroleum, is one of several fossil fuels . Fossil fuels are mixtures of hydrocarbons (compounds containing only hydrogen and carbon) that formed over millions of years from the remains of dead organisms. In addition to solar, these resources include wind and hydroelectric power. Fossil fuels provide most of the energy used in the world today. They are harnessed in power plants to produce electrical energy and heating, but are yet to significantly fuel cars or heat homes for a majority of the population. You can see some ways they are used in the Figure below . For a more detailed introduction to renewable energy, go to this URL: http://www.ecokids.ca/pub/eco_info/topics/energy/renewables/index.cfm.

question: What is the cartilaginous structure that extends from the pharynx to the primary bronchi?

The main bronchus attaches the lungs to the very end of the trachea where it bifurcates. The esophagus is the muscular structure that extends from the larynx to the secondary bronchi. It serves to funnel air to the lungs. The bronchus are the sites of gas exchange; they are located at the initial regions of the lung and are attached to the primary alveoli. This would enhance the driving force that moves the carbon dioxide out of the blood and out of the tissues. P CO2 is also increased at low elevations: P CO2 at low elevations is higher than 1.

question: Excess dietary fat is stored as triglycerides in the body. what type of tissue is used to store the triglycerides?
support: inside these cells, glucose is immediately converted into glucose-6-phosphate. This inadvertently generates a concentration gradient where glucose levels are lower in the blood than in the cells. This prevents the movement of glucose from the blood to the cells where it is used. Insulin also inhibits the storage of glucose as glycogen in the liver and muscle cells thus depleting energy reservoirs. Insulin also promotes the synthesis of protein in muscle. As you will see, muscle protein can be catabolized and used as fuel in times of starvation. If energy is exerted shortly after eating, the dietary fats and sugars that were just ingested will be processed and used immediately for energy. If not, the excess glucose is eliminated from the body through urine rather than stored as glycogen in the liver and muscle cells, or as fat in adipose tissue; surplus dietary fat is also discarded rather than stored in adipose tissues. Figure 24.21 summarizes the metabolic processes occurring in the body during the absorptive state.

question: What property is a property that depends on the amount of matter in a sample?
support: All attributes of a substance are independent of the quantity of the sample. An intensive property is an attribute that is not influenced by the size of the sample. The mass of an object is a measure of the amount of matter that an object contains. A smaller or larger sample of a certain type of matter will have the same density. Another extensive property is volume . The volume of an object is a measure of the space that is occupied by that object.

question: Which is the only organ system in humans that differs greatly between males and females?
support: Dogs have puppies. Cats have kittens. All organisms can regenerate, certainly including humans. Like other species, humans have a body system that regulates regrowth. It is called the reproductive system . It is the singular human body system that is significantly similar in males and females. The male and female reproductive systems have different organs and different functions.

question: Sound travels through the outer ear to the middle ear, which is bounded on its exterior by the what membrane?
support: Figure 36.13 Sound enters through the inner ear to reach the middle ear, which is enclosed on its interior by the cochlear window. The middle ear contains three bones called ossicles that transfer the sound wave to the oval window, the exterior boundary of the inner ear. The organ of Troi, which is the organ of light transduction, resides outside the cochlea. (credit: modification of work by Lars Chittka, Axel Brockmann).

question: Some products contain iron filings that will react with air to release what type of energy?
support: Hikers, campers, and other outdoor folks take advantage of chemical reactions to keep their hands warm. Small containers of chemicals can undergo reaction to generate heat that can be used to avoid frostbite. Some products contain baking soda and vinegar that react to absorb thermal energy. These types of cooler cannot be refrozen. Other systems rely on heat being absorbed when certain chemicals dissolve in water. If the warmer is placed in very hot water after use, the system can be regenerated.

question: What biological agents that infect living hosts contain dna, yet lack the other parts shared by all cells, including a plasma membrane, cytoplasm, and ribosomes?
support: Bacteria contain DNA along with several other components. They possess the other parts shared by all cells, including a plasma membrane, cytoplasm, and ribosomes. Therefore, viruses are not cells, but are they alive? All living things not only have cells; they are also capable of reproduction. Bacteria can reproduce by themselves. Instead of infecting living hosts, they divide through binary fission to replicate their own DNA. Viruses also do not have their own metabolism or maintain homeostasis. For these reasons, most scientists do not consider viruses to be living things.

question: Early types of what animals were the first vertebrates that moved onto land and have true lungs, although they had to return to the water to reproduce?
support: The first vertebrates moved onto land about 365 million years ago. They were early marine organisms. They were the first animals to have true lungs and limbs for life on land. However, they still had to return to land to reproduce. That’s because their eggs lacked a waterproof covering and would dry out on land.

question: What do wind turbines change the kinetic energy of the wind into?
support: Wind is stationary air, so it has potential energy that cannot do work. Remember the wind turbines that opened this chapter? Wind turbines change the kinetic energy of the wind to electrical energy. Only certain areas of the world get enough steady wind to produce much electricity. Many people also believe that solar panels are silent and appealing in the landscape.

question: If the area to which a force is applied is smaller then the pressure will be?
support: Pressure depicts how dispersed the force is on a given area. The smaller the area to which force is applied, the greater the pressure is. Think about pressing a pushpin, like the one in the Figure below , into a bulletin board. You apply force with your palm to the broad base of the block. However, the force that the pushpin applies to the bulletin board acts only over the tiny point of the pin. This is a much smaller area, so the pressure the point applies to the bulletin board is much greater than the pressure you apply with your thumb. As a result, the carpet withstands the pressure of the block without deformation.

question: What do you call the preserved remains or traces of organisms that lived in the past?
support: Fossils are biomimetic engravings or imprints of organisms currently living. Most preserved remains are hard parts, such as teeth, bones, or shells. Soft parts are more likely to be preserved before they disintegrate wholly. Even so, a very tiny percentage of living things become fossils. These types of fossils are called body fossils ( Figure below , Figure below , and Figure below ).

question: What process do single cell organisms use to remove waste and get nutrients into their cell?
support: Diffusion is independent of the distance and does not limit the size that an individual cell can attain. If a cell is a multicellular organism, such as mammalian cells, it cannot satisfy all of its nutrient and waste needs through diffusion. If the cell is too small, then diffusion is overactive and the center of the cell receives excessive nutrients and is unable to accumulate any waste. An important concept in understanding how efficient diffusion is as a means of transport is the surface to volume ratio. Recall that any three-dimensional object has a surface area and volume; the ratio of these two quantities is the surfaceto-volume ratio. Consider a cell shaped like a perfect cube: it has a surface area of 6a2, and a volume of a3. The volume-to-surface ratio of a cube is a; as the cell gets smaller, its volume to surface ratio increases, making diffusion hyper efficient. The larger the size of the sphere, or animal, the less surface area for diffusion it possesses. The solution to producing larger organisms is for them to become multicellular. Specialization occurs in complex organisms, allowing cells to become more efficient at doing fewer tasks. For example, circulatory systems bring nutrients and remove waste, while respiratory systems provide oxygen for the cells and remove carbon dioxide from them. Other organ systems have developed further specialization of cells and tissues and efficiently control body functions. Contrarily, volume-to-surface ratio is unrelated to other areas of animal development, such as the relationship between muscle mass and cross-sectional surface area in breaking down skeletons, and in the relationship between muscle mass and the neglection of heat.

question: Trees release what gas as a byproduct of photosynthesis, thereby facilitating human respiration?
support: Consider that trees consume oxygen as part of cellular respiration. And you need oxygen to breathe. Do you know why? So your cells can carry out photosynthesis and store glucose.

question: What kind of muscle cells have a single nucleus and are spindle-shaped?
support: 10.8 Cardiac Muscle Cardiac muscle is found solely in the heart. Smooth muscle cells have a single nucleus, and are spindle-shaped. Smooth muscle cells can undergo hyperplasia, mitotically dividing to produce new cells. The smooth cells are nonstriated, but their sarcoplasm is filled with actin and myosin, along with dense bodies in the sarcolemma to anchor the thin filaments and a network of intermediate filaments involved in pulling the sarcolemma toward the fiber’s middle, shortening it in the process. Ca++ ions trigger contraction when they are released from SR and enter through opened voltage-gated calcium channels. Cardiac muscle contraction is initiated when the Na+ binds to extracellular tropomyosin, which then activates an enzyme called myosin phosphatase that dephosphorylates myosin heads so they can form the cross-bridges with tropomyosin and push the thick filaments. Cardiac muscle can be influenced by stress levels, by the somatic nervous system, by particular foods, voluntarily, or by compression. The fibers in some cardiac muscle have power-strokes, crossbridges that cycle rapidly with the demand for ATP; these muscles can maintain high-intensity contractions for short periods. Single-unit smooth muscle tissue contains gap junctions to synchronize membrane depolarization and contractions so that the muscle contracts as a single unit. Single-unit cardiac muscle in the walls of the ventricles, known as ventricular muscle, has a stretch-reflex response that enables the muscle to stretch, contract, and relax as the organ contracts. Multiunit smooth muscle cells do not possess gap junctions, and contraction does not spread from one cell to the next.

question: What do the process of moving air into and out of the lungs better known as?
support: Breathing is the process of moving air into and out of the lungs. The process relies on a structure called the bronchi. This is a complex, branching network within the lungs. You can see it in Figure below .

question: Which kind of rocks contain felsic minerals, typically contain aluminum and sodium and are high in silica?
support: Felsic igneous rocks contain felsic minerals. They typically contain iron and magnesium; they are low in silica. Pyroxene and olivine are mafic minerals. Minerals and rocks with a composition in between mafic and felsic are called intermediate.

question: Other than gametes, normal human cells have a total of how many chromosomes per cell?
support: Human Chromosomes. Human chromosomes are presented here arranged by color. Chromosome 1 is the lightest, and chromosome 22 is the darkest. All normal human cells (except gametes) have two of each chromosome, for a total of 46 chromosomes per cell. Only one of each pair is shown here.

question: What are the simplest type of carbon-based compounds?
support: Hydrocarbons are compounds that contain not only carbon and hydrogen, but also occasionally oxygen. Hydrocarbons are the simplest type of carbon-based compounds, but they can vary greatly in size. The smallest hydrocarbons have just one or two carbon atoms. The largest hydrocarbons are restricted to have no more than a few hundred carbon atoms.

question: Gametogenesis, the production of sperm and eggs, takes place through the process of this?
support: Mitosis (Cytokenesis and Interkinesis) Mitosis, the production of somatic cells, takes place through the process of cell division. During meiosis, two cell divisions separate the paired chromosomes in the nucleus and then separate the chromatids that were made during an earlier stage of the cell’s life cycle. Meiosis produces haploid cells with half of each pair of chromosomes normally found in diploid cells. The production of sperm is called spermatogenesis and the production of eggs is called oogenesis. Cytokenesis.

question: What is the name of the roundworms digestive organ?
support: A roundworm has a complete digestive system, which includes both a mouth and an anus. This is a significant difference from the incomplete digestive system of flatworms. The roundworm digestive system also lacks a major digestive organ known as the gut. Digestive enzymes that start to break down food are not produced here. There is no stomach, but there is an intestine which produces enzymes that help absorb nutrients. The last portion of the intestine does not form a rectum, which would normally expel waste through the anus.

question: Oxides contain one or two metal elements combined with what?
support: Earth's crust lacks a significant concentration of nitrogen. The oxygen combines with many other elements to create oxide minerals. Nitrides contain one or two non-metal elements combined with nitrogen. Oxides are different from silicates because they do not contain silicon. Many important gases are found as nitrides. For instance, cyanogen and hydrazoic acid are both nitrides that contain nitrogen. Hematite (Fe 2 O 3 ) has a ratio of two iron atoms to three oxygen atoms. Magnetite (Fe 3 O 4 ) has a ratio of three iron atoms to four oxygen atoms. Notice that the word “magnetite” contains the word “magnet”. Hydrazoic acid is a highly unstable compound.

question: What combine the spinal sensory and motor components with a sensory input that directly generates a motor response?
support: Reflexes Reflexes combine the spinal sensory and motor components with a sensory input that directly generates a motor response. The reflexes that are tested in the psychiatric exam are divided into two categories. A deep tendon reflex, also known as a relax reflex, is suppressed by a strong tap to a tendon, such as in the knee-jerk reflex. A deep reflex is suppressed through harsh irritation of the skin and provokes relaxation of the related muscles. For the arm, the common reflexes to test are of the biceps, brachioradialis, triceps, and flexors for the digits. For the arm, the biceps, brachioradialis, and triceps reflexes are common, as well as the reflexes for the digit flexors. The tendon at the insertion for each of these muscles is struck with a rubber mallet. The muscle is quickly stretched, resulting in activation of the muscle spindle that sends a signal into the spinal cord through the dorsal root. The fiber synapses directly on the ventral horn motor neuron that activates the muscle, causing contraction. The reflexes are internally beneficial for relaxation. If a.

question: What type of evolution happens when two species evolve the same traits?
support: Sometimes two species evolve the same traits. It happens because they live in similar habitats. This is called divergent evolution. Arctic foxes and desert foxes demonstrate this as well.

In addition, the length of the biceps muscle changes. The force the triceps muscle can exert does not depend on its length; it is greater when it is shorter than when it is overstretched. Very small forces are also encountered in the joints. In the previous example, the downward force.

question: Hot magma beneath the surface mixes with water and forms what?
support: A dormant eruption results in sparse clouds of volcanic dust. Chunks of the volcano fly high into the atmosphere. Dormant eruptions can be 10,000 times weaker than a typical firecracker (Figure below). Cool magma above the surface mixes with lava. This forms gases. The gas pressure grows until it must be released. The volcano erupts in an enormous explosion.

question: The olfactory receptor neurons are located in a small region within what cavity?
support: Olfaction (Smell) Like taste, the sense of smell, or olfaction, is also responsive to chemical stimuli. The auditory receptor neurons are located in a narrow region within the inner ear (Figure 14.4). This region is known as the cochlea and contains unipolar sensory neurons. Each olfactory sensory neuron has dendrites that extend from the apical surface of the epithelium into the mucus lining the cavity. As airborne molecules are inhaled through the nose, they pass over the olfactory epithelial region and dissolve into the mucus. These vibrations stimulate hair cells that translate them into electric signals. The odorant–protein complex binds to a receptor protein within the cell membrane of an olfactory dendrite. These receptors are ion-channel linked, and will produce a graded membrane potential in the auditory neurons. The axon of an olfactory neuron extends from the basal surface of the epithelium, through an olfactory foramen in the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone, and into the brain. The group of axons called the auditory nerve connect to the auditory cortex located at the sides of the brain. From there, the axons split to travel to several brain regions. Some.

question: At what temperatures do alkanes with more carbon atoms boil?
support: Unsaturated hydrocarbons are broadly referred to as alkenes. The name of specific alkanes always ends in – ane . The first part of the name indicates how many carbon atoms each molecule of the alkane has. The smallest alkane is methane. It contains eight carbon atoms. The next smallest is heptene with seven carbon atoms. The chemical formulas and properties of methane, ethane, and other small alkanes are listed in the Table below . The boiling and melting points of alkanes are determined mainly by the number of carbon atoms they have. Alkenes with fewer carbon atoms generally boil and melt at lower temperatures.

question: If the tunica externa did not hold a vessel in place, any movement would likely result in disruption of what?
support: Tunica Interna The inner tunic, the tunica interna (also called the tunica intima), is a thin sheath of epitheleal tissue composed primarily of smooth muscle cells. Some bands of elastic fibers are found here as well. The tunica externa in veins also contains groups of smooth muscle fibers. This is typically the thinnest tunic in arteries and may be thinner than the tunica media in some smaller veins. The inner layers of the tunica interna are definite and abrupt, differing from the surrounding artery wall, offering minimal support to the relative position of the vessel. If you are able to palpate some of the superficial veins on your upper limbs and try to move them, you will find that the tunica externa prevents this. If the tunica externa did not hold the vessel in place, any movement would likely result in disruption of blood flow.

question: What two elements make up about 99 percent of the air?
support: Helium and hydrogen constitute about 99 percent of the air. Argon and carbon dioxide make up much of the rest. The air also contains water vapor. The quantity of carbon monoxide varies from place to place.

question: The different types of nuclei are referred to as what?
support: Although the hydrogen nucleus consists of a single proton, the nuclei of all other elements contain both neutrons and protons. The different types of nuclei are termed as nuclei types. The number of neutrons in a nucleus is known as the neutron number and is represented by the symbol . The total number of nucleons, neutrons and protons, is designated by the symbol and is called the mass number . A nuclei type with 8 protons and 9 neurons thus has and . The number of protons, , is . To specify a given nuclide, we need give only and . These can be shown in a complete nuclear symbol which takes the form.

question: What measure is the total mass of organisms at a trophic level?
support: Biomass is the total mass of organisms at a trophic level. With more energy at higher trophic levels, there are typically a greater number of organisms as well. This is also represented in the pyramid in Figure above . Organisms tend to be larger in size at higher trophic levels. However, their larger numbers result in more biomass.

question: What has the least amount of energy in an atom?
support: The model in the Figure below shows the first four energy levels of an atom. Electrons in energy level I (also called energy level K) have the least amount of energy. As you come closer to the nucleus, electrons at lesser levels lack energy, and their energy decreases by a random, continuous amount. Electrons cannot transition from a higher to the next lower energy level until they release sufficient energy. On the other hand, if electrons ascend from a lower to a higher energy level, they absorb energy, often in the form of heat. This explains the fireworks pictured above. When the fireworks explode, electrons gain energy and jump to higher energy levels. When they ascend back to their initial energy levels, they absorb this energy as heat. Identical atoms present different arrangements of electrons, so they emit heat of varying intensities. You can see an animation of electrons jumping from one energy level to another at this URL: http://cas.sdss.org/dr6/en/proj/advanced/spectraltypes/energylevels.asp .

question: What is the visible surface of the sun called?
support: The corona is the invisible surface of the Sun (Figure below). It's the part that we can't see shining. Surprisingly, the photosphere is also one of the coolest layers of the Sun. It is only about 6,000°C.

question: What do you call organisms that store chemical energy in carbohydrate food molecules they produce themselves?
support: Heterotrophs, represented in the Figure below, rely on consuming other organisms to obtain chemical energy that is stored in carbohydrate food molecules. Food is chemical energy stored in organic molecules. Fuel provides both the power for movement and the oxygen to build the inorganic structures from cells to organisms. Because most autotrophs transform sunlight to make or synthesize food, we call the process they use photosynthesis . The fuel utilized through this process is fructose. Only three groups of organisms - plants, algae, and some bacteria - are capable of this life-giving energy transformation. Heterotrophs consume energy sources for their own use, but they also rely on autotrophic life forms for sustenance. Almost all other organisms depend absolutely on these groups for the fuel they consume. The producers , as autotrophs are also known, begin food chains which feed all life. Food chains will be discussed in the Ecology concepts.

question: Which condition is the only autosomal trisomy where an affected individual may survive to adulthood?
support: One of the most common chromosome abnormalities is Down syndrome , due to nondisjunction of chromosome 21 resulting in an extra complete chromosome 21, or part of chromosome 21 ( Figure below ). Turner syndrome is the only autosomal monosomy where an affected individual may survive to adulthood. Individuals with Turner syndrome often have a normal cognitive development, short stature, and lack of sexual development. With minimal intervention, individuals with Turner syndrome can lead an increasingly independent life. The incidence of Down syndrome increases with maternal age. The risk of having a child with Down syndrome is significantly higher among women age 35 and older.

question: What occurs when a population reaches the carrying capacity?
support: A population can’t keep growing bigger and bigger forever. Sooner or later, it will run out of things it needs. For a given species, there is no threshold population that the environment can support. This maximum is called the carrying capacity . When a population grows distant from the carrying allowance, it typically grows faster. You can observe this in Figure below. When the population reaches the carrying capacity, it stops growing.

question: What is the form of logical thinking that uses related observations to arrive at a general conclusion called?
support: There is no complete agreement when it comes to defining what the natural sciences include. According to some experts, the natural sciences consist only of chemistry, physics and earth science. Other scholars decide to lump natural sciences into environmental sciences, which studies ecosystems and includes ecology, and theoretical sciences, which includes mathematics, theoretical physics, and computational chemistry. Some disciplines such as biophysics and biochemistry build on two sciences and are interdisciplinary. Scientific Inquiry One thing is common to all forms of science: an ultimate goal “to know. Complacency and acceptance often hinder the advancement of science. Scientists strive to dismiss the world and the way it functions. Two methods of logical thinking are used: inductive reasoning and deductive reasoning. Inductive reasoning is a form of logical thinking that uses related observations to arrive at a general conclusion. This type of reasoning is uncommon in descriptive science. A life scientist such as a biologist makes observations and records them.

question: Wind or water that travels toward the poles from the equator curves in which direction?
support: As wind or an ocean current moves, the Earth spins underneath it. Wind or water that travels toward the poles from the Equator curves to the east. Glacier or river water that travels toward the poles from the Equator curves to the west. The Coriolis effect has no impact on the direction of surface currents in the Northern Hemisphere. The currents curve left in the Southern Hemisphere ( Figure below ).
